frame.name: Connectors
frame.definition: <def-root>The <fen>Connector</fen> is an artifact created to affix a <fen>Connected_item</fen> or to bind onto a <fen>Fixed_location</fen> and is primarily so used. A more specific <fen>Use</fen> may also be specified. Certain words in this frame (e.g. <ment>bond, chain</ment> in the phrase <ment>in chains</ment>) indicate specifically that the <fen>Connector</fen> is being used to immobilize something. <fen>Connector</fen>s have a wide variety of physical forms: long, thin, and flexible for tying (<ment>ropes, bonds, withies</ment>); solid, with a shape corresponding to holes in the entities to be connected (<ment>bolts, nails, pegs</ment>); and liquid (<ment>glues, adhesives, pastes</ment>). <ex>A waterproof <fex name="Connector"><t>adhesive</t></fex> should be used for this exterior job.</ex> <ex><x><fex name="Item">His</fex> <t><fex name="Connector">bonds</fex></t></x> had to be <gov>loosened</gov> before they could be cut.</ex> <ex>She <gov>jerked</gov> <x>on <fex name="Connected_item">His</fex> <fex name="Loc">neck</fex> <fex name="Connector"><t>rope</t></fex></x> again, to keep his attention.</ex> <ex>I think they <gov>cut</gov> <x>his <fex name="Use">bike</fex> <fex name="Connector"><t>chain</t></fex></x> with bolt cutters.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Connector
FE.definition: <def-root><fen>Connector</fen> identifies the entity or substance that forms the bond that maintains the <fen>Item</fen> in a fixed position; it is usually expressed in a "with"-PP. <ex>The robber tied Harry to the chair with a <fex name="Connector"><t>rope</t></fex>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Connected_item
FE.definition: <def-root>This FE identifies the entity that is attached to the <fen>Connector</fen> in such a way as to stabilize their position or to immobilize them. <ex>The robber tied <fex name="Item">Harry 's</fex> <t>bonds</t> very tight.</ex> <ex><fex name="Item">Her</fex> <t>rope</t> was stuck between two rocks and she couldn't move far.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Fixed_location
FE.definition: <def-root>This FE identifies the location to which the <fen>Connector</fen> is attached. <ex>The <t>rope</t> <fex name="Loc">around his neck</fex> was like a noose, but it hung down as if it were a macabre necktie.</ex> </def-root>

FE.name: Use
FE.definition: <def-root>The items that a <fen>Connector</fen> usually attaches or the type of activity the attaching is generally for. <ex>If the <fex name="Use">safety</fex> <t>rope</t> snaps, you're done for.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Material
FE.definition:
<def-root><fen>Material</fen> identifies the material of which the <fen>Connector</fen> is made.
<ex><fex name="Mat">Silk</fex> <t>rope</t> is surprisingly strong for its diameter.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Type
FE.definition:
<def-root><fen>Type</fen> designates the type of <fen>Connector</fen>. Often the <fen>Type</fen> labels part of a multi-word or compound word target.
</def-root>

FE.name: Name
FE.definition:
<def-root>The term used to refer to a <fen>Connector</fen>.
<ex>Remove <t>peg</t> <fex name="nam">3-B</fex>, if possible.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Creator
FE.definition:
<def-root>The individual or group that creates a <fen>Connector</fen>.
<ex>I tried to find the <fex name="cre">DuPont</fex> <t>adhesive</t> , but they did n't have any .</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Time_of_creation
FE.definition:
<def-root>The time at which the <fen>Connector</fen> comes to be.
<ex>The <t>bolts</t> <fex name="tim">of the 19th century</fex> had non-standardized thread widths.</ex></def-root>

lexUnit.name: ribbon.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a long, narrow strip of fabric, used for tying something or for decoration.

lexUnit.name: rope.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a length of stout cord made by twisting together strands of hemp, sisal, nylon, etc.

lexUnit.name: thread.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a long, thin strand of cotton, nylon, or other fibres used in sewing or weaving.

lexUnit.name: string.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: material consisting of threads of cotton, hemp, etc. twisted together to form a thin leng

lexUnit.name: cord.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: long thin string or rope made from several twisted strands.

lexUnit.name: chain.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a connected flexible series of metal links used for fastening, pulling, etc., or in jewellery.

lexUnit.name: bond.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: physical restraints used to hold someone prisoner.

lexUnit.name: adhesive.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: a malleable or liquid substance which can be applied to points of contact between objects to join them.

lexUnit.name: tape.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a strip of paper or plastic coated with adhesive, used to stick things together.

lexUnit.name: glue.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: an adhesive substance used for sticking objects or materials together.

lexUnit.name: bolt.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a long pin with a head that screws into a nut, used to fasten things together, a bar that slides into a socket to fasten a door or window

lexUnit.name: nut.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a small flat piece of metal or other material, typically square or hexagonal, with a threaded hole through it for screwing on to a bolt.

lexUnit.name: nail.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a small metal spike with a broadened flat head, driven typically into wood to join things together or to serve as a hook.

lexUnit.name: peg.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a short projecting pin or bolt used for hanging things on, securing something in place, or marking a position.

lexUnit.name: strap.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a strip of leather, cloth, or other flexible material, used for fastening, securing, carrying, or holding on to.

lexUnit.name: tack.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a small, sharp broad-headed nail, a drawing pin

lexUnit.name: staple.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: a U-shaped piece of wire or metal, usually sharpened at both ends, used to attach objects (with the help of a device) by piercing and immobilizing them at some point(s).

lexUnit.name: withy.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a tough flexible branch of an osier or other willow, used for tying, binding, or basketry.

lexUnit.name: tie.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a thing that ties.

lexUnit.name: lace.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a cord or leather strip passed through eyelets or hooks to fasten a shoe or garment.

lexUnit.name: shoelace.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a cord or leather strip passed through eyelets or hooks on opposite sides of a shoe and pulled tight and fastened.

lexUnit.name: wire.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: metal drawn out into a thin flexible thread or rod.

lexUnit.name: screw.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a short, slender, sharp-pointed metal pin with a raised helical thread running around it and a slotted head, used to join things together by being rotated in under pressure.

lexUnit.name: link.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: something that connects.

lexUnit.name: connector.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: something that serves to connect items together.

lexUnit.name: trace.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: the lines used to attach a horse's harness to a wagon or other horse-drawn vehicle
